qa_list.question: What are the four initial crack angles studied in the text?
qa_list.ref_chunk: of 0◦ is the most unfavourable for crack propagation. The initial crack angle has little effect on the K–a relationship. Metals 2023, 13, x FOR PEER REVIEW 9 of 18 (a) (b) Figure 10. Comparison of experimental and numerical results: (a) a–N; (b) Crack propagation path of Q550E-1. 4.3. Parametric Analysis 4.3.1. Initial Crack Angle To study the eﬀect of the initial crack angle on the crack propagation, initial cracks at four angles of 0°, 30°, 45°, and 60° were prefabricated on the specimens in this study. The initial crack length was 1.5 mm with a 7 kN load level, thickness of 8 mm, and stress ratio of 0.1. As shown in Figure 11, the trends of crack propagation at diﬀerent angles were the same. The curves are very close to each other when the initial angles are in the range of 0°–45°, but they change signiﬁcantly at 60°. Thus, there is a critical angle of crack propa-gation. An encrypted approximation at 45°–60° was carried out. It was found that the crit-ical angle was 52.5°, where the crack growth rate suddenly changed. According to the K–N curve, with an increase in the initial crack propagation angle, the stress intensity factor caused by crack tip fracture decreases, and the reduction range is as high as 59%. There-fore, an initial crack angle of 0° is the most unfavourable for crack propagation. The initial crack angle has little eﬀect on the K–a relationship. Metals 2023, 13, 1496 9 of 18 Figure 10. Comparison of experimental and numerical results: (a) a–N; (b) Crack propagation path of Q550E-1. 4.3.2. Crack Depth Ratio Figure 12 shows the crack growth life curves with six crack depth ratios for a thickness of 8 mm and a stress ratio of 0.1. The fatigue life decreased with increasing depth ratio. When the crack depth ratio was repeatedly increased by 0.05, the fatigue life decreased by 37%, 39%, 49%, 40%, and 54%. The relationship curve between the stress intensity factor and crack length was not affected by the crack depth ratio. The change in the stress ratio did not affect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for different crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. Metals 2023, 13, x FOR PEER REVIEW 10 of 18 (a) (b) (c) Figure 11. Inﬂuence of the critical angle: (a) a–N; (b) K–N; (c) K–a. Metals 2023, 13, 1496 10 of 18 Figure 11. Inﬂuence of the critical angle: (a) a–N; (b) K–N; (c) K–a. 4.3.2. Crack Depth Ratio Figure 12 shows the crack growth life curves with six crack depth ratios for a thick-ness of 8 mm and a stress ratio of 0.1. The fatigue life decreased with increasing depth ratio. When the crack depth ratio was repeatedly increased by 0.05, the fatigue life de-creased by 37%, 39%, 49%, 40%, and 54%. The relationship curve between the stress inten-sity factor and crack length was not aﬀected by the crack depth ratio. The change in the stress ratio did not aﬀect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for diﬀerent crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. (a) (b) (c) Figure 12. Inﬂuence of the crack depth ratio: (a) a–N; (b) K–a; (c) K–R. Figure 13 shows a stress diagram of crack propagation of the crack tip along the thick-ness direction with diﬀerent crack depth ratios, where the horizontal direction represents the crack propagation length, the vertical direction represents the specimen thickness, and labels 1–2 represent the path of the crack tip along the thickness direction. In this case, the load was 7 kN, the stress ratio was 0.1, and the thickness was 8 mm. Regardless of the crack depth ratio, the maximum K mainly occurs in the middle position, and a crack Metals 2023, 13, x FOR PEER REVIEW 11 of 18 Metals 2023, 13, 1496 11 of 18 Figure 12. Inﬂuence of the crack depth ratio: (a) a–N; (b) K–a; (c) K–R. Figure 13 shows a stress diagram of crack propagation of the crack tip along the thick- ness direction with different crack depth ratios, where the horizontal direction represents the crack propagation length, the vertical direction represents the specimen thickness, and labels 1–2 represent the path of the crack tip along the thickness direction. In this case, the load was 7 kN, the stress ratio was 0.1, and the thickness was 8 mm. Regardless of the crack depth ratio, the maximum K mainly occurs in the middle position, and a crack initiates in the middle position in the thickness direction and gradually extends to both sides, eventually causing the entire surface to fracture. The K values increase with the crack depth ratio, which leads to a higher possibility of crack tip fracture. In engineering practice, the effective crack length. i.e., the sum of the notch depth and crack length, must be monitored to detect these hidden cracks. initiates in the middle position in the thickness direction and gradually extends to both sides, eventually causing the entire surface to fracture. The K values increase with the crack depth ratio, which leads to a higher possibility of crack tip fracture. In engineering practice, the eﬀective crack length. i.e., the sum of the notch depth and crack length, must be monitored to detect these hidden cracks. Figure 13. Stress diagram of crack propagation with diﬀerent crack depth ratios of (A) 0.2, (B) 0.25, (C) 0.3, (D) 0.35, (E) 0.4, and (F) 0.45. 4.3.3. Stress Ratio Previous studies have shown that stress ratios of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.5 can well demon-strate the eﬀect of stress ratios on crack propagation [24]. For this reason, these stress ratios with a thickness of 10 mm and a load of 36 kN were used in the FEM to

Initial Crack Angle To study the eﬀect of the initial crack angle on the crack propagation, initial cracks at four angles of 0°, 30°, 45°, and 60° were prefabricated on the specimens in this study. The initial crack length was 1.5 mm with a 7 kN load level, thickness of 8 mm, and stress ratio of 0.1. As shown in Figure 11, the trends of crack propagation at diﬀerent angles were the same. The curves are very close to each other when the initial angles are in the range of 0°–45°, but they change signiﬁcantly at 60°. Thus, there is a critical angle of crack propa-gation. An encrypted approximation at 45°–60° was carried out. It was found that the crit-ical angle was 52.5°, where the crack growth rate suddenly changed. According to the K–N curve, with an increase in the initial crack propagation angle, the stress intensity factor caused by crack tip fracture decreases, and the reduction range is as high as 59%. The change in the stress ratio did not affect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for different crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. qa_list.answer: It decreases, with a reduction range as high as 59%.

qa_list.question: How does the fatigue life change with increasing crack depth ratio?
qa_list.answer: The fatigue life decreases as the crack depth ratio increases.

qa_list.question: What remains constant for different crack depth ratios according to the text?
qa_list.answer: The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R.

The curves are very close to each other when the initial angles are in the range of 0°–45°, but they change signiﬁcantly at 60°. Thus, there is a critical angle of crack propa-gation. An encrypted approximation at 45°–60° was carried out. It was found that the crit-ical angle was 52.5°, where the crack growth rate suddenly changed. According to the K–N curve, with an increase in the initial crack propagation angle, the stress intensity factor caused by crack tip fracture decreases, and the reduction range is as high as 59%. There-fore, an initial crack angle of 0° is the most unfavourable for crack propagation. The initial crack angle has little eﬀect on the K–a relationship. Metals 2023, 13, 1496 9 of 18 Figure 10. Comparison of experimental and numerical results: (a) a–N; (b) Crack propagation path of Q550E-1. 4.3.2. Crack Depth Ratio Figure 12 shows the crack growth life curves with six crack depth ratios for a thickness of 8 mm and a stress ratio of 0.1. The fatigue life decreased with increasing depth ratio. When the crack depth ratio was repeatedly increased by 0.05, the fatigue life decreased by 37%, 39%, 49%, 40%, and 54%. The relationship curve between the stress intensity factor and crack length was not affected by the crack depth ratio. The change in the stress ratio did not affect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for different crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. Metals 2023, 13, x FOR PEER REVIEW 10 of 18 (a) (b) (c) Figure 11. Inﬂuence of the critical angle: (a) a–N; (b) K–N; (c) K–a. Metals 2023, 13, 1496 10 of 18 Figure 11. Inﬂuence of the critical angle: (a) a–N; (b) K–N; (c) K–a. 4.3.2. Crack Depth Ratio Figure 12 shows the crack growth life curves with six crack depth ratios for a thick-ness of 8 mm and a stress ratio of 0.1. The fatigue life decreased with increasing depth ratio. When the crack depth ratio was repeatedly increased by 0.05, the fatigue life de-creased by 37%, 39%, 49%, 40%, and 54%. The relationship curve between the stress inten-sity factor and crack length was not aﬀected by the crack depth ratio. The change in the stress ratio did not aﬀect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for diﬀerent crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. (a) (b) (c) Figure 12. Inﬂuence of the crack depth ratio: (a) a–N; (b) K–a; (c) K–R. Figure 13 shows a stress diagram of crack propagation of the crack tip along the thick-ness direction with diﬀerent crack depth ratios, where the horizontal direction represents the crack propagation length, the vertical direction represents the specimen thickness, and labels 1–2 represent the path of the crack tip along the thickness direction. In this case, the load was 7 kN, the stress ratio was 0.1, and the thickness was 8 mm. Regardless of the crack depth ratio, the maximum K mainly occurs in the middle position, and a crack Metals 2023, 13, x FOR PEER REVIEW 11 of 18 Metals 2023, 13, 1496 11 of 18 Figure 12. Inﬂuence of the crack depth ratio: (a) a–N; (b) K–a; (c) K–R. Figure 13 shows a stress diagram of crack propagation of the crack tip along the thick- ness direction with different crack depth ratios, where the horizontal direction represents the crack propagation length, the vertical direction represents the specimen thickness, and labels 1–2 represent the path of the crack tip along the thickness direction. In this case, the load was 7 kN, the stress ratio was 0.1, and the thickness was 8 mm. Regardless of the crack depth ratio, the maximum K mainly occurs in the middle position, and a crack initiates in the middle position in the thickness direction and gradually extends to both sides, eventually causing the entire surface to fracture. The K values increase with the crack depth ratio, which leads to a higher possibility of crack tip fracture. In engineering practice, the effective crack length. i.e., the sum of the notch depth and crack length, must be monitored to detect these hidden cracks. initiates in the middle position in the thickness direction and gradually extends to both sides, eventually causing the entire surface to fracture. The K values increase with the crack depth ratio, which leads to a higher possibility of crack tip fracture. In engineering practice, the eﬀective crack length. i.e., the sum of the notch depth and crack length, must be monitored to detect these hidden cracks. Figure 13. For this reason, these stress ratios with a thickness of 10 mm and a load of 36 kN were used in the FEM to

qa_list.question: Where does the maximum K mainly occur during crack propagation?
qa_list.answer: The maximum K mainly occurs in the middle position.

qa_list.question: What must be monitored in engineering practice to detect hidden cracks?
qa_list.answer: The effective crack length, which is the sum of the notch depth and crack length.

The change in the stress ratio did not affect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for different crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. Crack Depth Ratio Figure 12 shows the crack growth life curves with six crack depth ratios for a thick-ness of 8 mm and a stress ratio of 0.1. The fatigue life decreased with increasing depth ratio. When the crack depth ratio was repeatedly increased by 0.05, the fatigue life de-creased by 37%, 39%, 49%, 40%, and 54%. The relationship curve between the stress inten-sity factor and crack length was not aﬀected by the crack depth ratio. The change in the stress ratio did not aﬀect the cracking state under the same crack depth ratio, as shown in Figure 12c. The ratio of the cracking K to the stress ratio R was constant for diﬀerent crack depth ratios, and the ratio became higher as the depth increased. (a) (b) (c) Figure 12. Figure 13 shows a stress diagram of crack propagation of the crack tip along the thick- ness direction with different crack depth ratios, where the horizontal direction represents the crack propagation length, the vertical direction represents the specimen thickness, and labels 1–2 represent the path of the crack tip along the thickness direction. In this case, the load was 7 kN, the stress ratio was 0.1, and the thickness was 8 mm. Regardless of the crack depth ratio, the maximum K mainly occurs in the middle position, and a crack initiates in the middle position in the thickness direction and gradually extends to both sides, eventually causing the entire surface to fracture. The K values increase with the crack depth ratio, which leads to a higher possibility of crack tip fracture. In engineering practice, the effective crack length. i.e., the sum of the notch depth and crack length, must be monitored to detect these hidden cracks. initiates in the middle position in the thickness direction and gradually extends to both sides, eventually causing the entire surface to fracture. The K values increase with the crack depth ratio, which leads to a higher possibility of crack tip fracture.
